root.title: Country Loaf (Pain de Campagne)
root.authorInfo: Deb Lindsey for The Washington Post
root.para: Washington author Sam Fromartz has been making sourdough variations of this yeast bread for years. Here, he adds fermented cider for flavor. A mild beer may be substituted; an IPA would be too bitter. The loaf is sized to last a few days.
The optional tablespoon of water is to compensate for the variable absorption of the rye and whole-wheat flours.

You'll need a colander, a pastry cloth or clean dish towel and a covered cast-iron or enameled cast-iron pot. Make Ahead: The dough needs four 20-minute rests, plus an 8-to-24-hour stay in the refrigerator and a final 1 1/2-hour rise.
Storage Notes: Store the cooled loaf in a paper bag for a day, and store in a plastic bag for a few days after that. Do not refrigerate.
root.servingInfo: SERVINGS: Tested size: 10-12 servings; makes one 11-ounce loaf 10 to 12 slices

item.ing: white bread flour plus more for dusting
instant yeast or bread machine yeast
dry fermented cidermay substitute Pilsener beer see headnote
lukewarm water 80 degrees plus an optional 1 tablespoon

directions.heading: DIRECTIONS
directions.para:
Whisk together the flours yeast and salt in a mixing bowl
Combine the cider and waterin a liquid measuring cup. Add the liquid to the flour mixture; use a spatula or bench scraper or your hand moistened with water to blend them for about a minute.The dough should be shaggy yet cohesive. Cover the bowl with a towel let the dough rest for 20 minutes Moisten your kneading hand If the dough seems stiff, add the optional tablespoon of water
Stretch one edge of the dough still in the bowl then press it into the center of the bowl Repeat this about a dozen times, moving clockwise to catch all sides of the dough This should take 1-2 minutes
Turn the dough over so the seams are on the bottom Cover and let rest for 20 minutes. Repeat the clockwise stretching and folding two more times with 20minute rests after each . Cover and refrigerate 8 hours24 hours The dough should have doubled. If it hasn't, leave it on the counter until it does. Lightly flour a work surface Use a pastry cloth or clean dish towel to line a round colander Dust clothwithflour Transfer the dough to the floured work surface
Fold the edges toward the center to create a round shape turning it over so the seams are on the bottom Let it rest for 5 minutes then transfer to the colander, seam side up Cover with a towel and let the dough rise1 1/2 hours
Thirtyminutes before baking, place a cast-iron Dutch oven lid on enameled cast-iron pot lid on in the ovenpreheat to 475 degrees Carefully remove the hot pot from the oven Turn the dough out onto the counter so the seams are on the bottom Use kitchen scissors make snips8 on the top of the dough in an evenly spaced spoke pattern, each about 1/4inch deep
Lift the dough and carefully drop into hot potImmediately cover with the hot lid Bake for 30 minutes, then reduce the heat to 450 degrees Uncover and bake for 8-10 minutes until the crust is dark brown Try to minimize the amount of time the oven door is open The bread is done when its internal temperature register205degrees on an instant-read thermometer and the loaf sounds hollow when knocked on the underside Transfer the loaf to a wire rack to cool for at least 1 hour before cutting
